A brief account by Dr. McGee, of the Nurse Corps of the Army as it exists now, has recently been published in the journal of the Association of Military Surgeons of the United States. A pre vious article describe! the conditions attending the appointment of trained women nurses for army duty, which began In May, 1808 , and culminated n September, when about 1200 were employed. Between then and tbe pres ent time they have served In the Uni ted States, Cuba, Porto Rico, Hawaii Japan and tbe Philippines, and even In the Chinese campaign. The number Is now fixed at 100 on active duty, with a small body of reserves who have seen active service and are ready to an- wer future calls. Trained nurses are permanently stationed at the army hospital at San Francisco, at the one for tuberculosis at Fort Bayard. N. M. ind at the largest hospitals In the Phil ipplnes. They are temporarily sent to iny post where they may be needed. They serve under a section of tbe army reorganization law framed in 1900 , which provided that the medical de partment should consist of specified medical officers, of the enlisted men of the hospital corps, and of the nurse rorps female. A superintendent Is stationed in the surgeon generals office and a chief nurse Is at each of the hospitals where nurses are serving. Recent regulations provide for an ex amination In nursing, cooking and al lied subjects before promotion from the grade of nurse to that of chief nurse. Women are employed with marked success as teachers of nursing and cooking In. the two schools main tained to give brief preliminary In struction to tb? hospital corps recrnlts. Dr. McGee urges that In the future the nurse corps be more largely util ized In giving systematic ward train ing to fit the hospital corps men for their duties In the smaller hospitals where they have no trained supervis ion. She also recommends the gradual formation of a large corps of reserves who have received some post-graduate military training.American Medicine.

Y.Mrs. Eliza Mur ray, believed to be over 90, and 37- year-old Clarence McGee were mar ried before a capacity audience in the Methodist church here. Both are residents of Brushton, a j small northern New York village1 about two miles from here near the Canadian border. The bride gave her age as 80 for the marriage license, but her son James, who is 69, said she -was over 90. The bride has three living sons and daughters. Her first husband, Charlie, died at the age of 98

document.text: Protected From Lynching. Shreveport, La. Special.   Dick Craighead, the half-brother of Isaac A. McGee, who is charged with the murder of Mrs. McGee and her 10- year-old son, near Athens, yesterday, was saved from a mob, which threat ened the parish jail at Homer, in which he was confined. The Claiborne Guards were called out and Sheriff Kirkpatrick later summoned all the able-bodied men of Homer to assist him in protecting the jail. The mob was about 150 strong, hut seeing that the Sheriff was determined to protect Craighead it finally dispersed.

document.text: OWÎ Correspondent Henry R. Lieberman, who accompanied the , team, related the story. The team was led by Lt. Col.  Willis H. Bird of Landsdowne, Pa. j As the transport settled down on the Japanese air strip, high ranking i Japanese officers, including one j identified as Lt. Gen. Yoshjo Kot- suki, commander of the enemy  forces in Korea, approached. He re-  fused the request of the Americans I to see Allied prisoners and also re- j fused to give the names and nation-  alities of the prisoners. Drinks, Songsand Guns. The mercy team and the crew of the plane put up for the night be cause the Japanese commandant was unable to. get enough gasoline for the C-47 Us leave immediately. The Japanese meantime brought up two tanks and set up trench mor tars around the plane. A 37 milli meter cannon covered the party. During the night the Japanese en tertained the Americans with beer sake and Japanese songs. Flight Officer Edward McGee of Durant, Okla.p_ commenting on the scene said If someone had told me two weeks agp Id be in a setup like this I would have turned him over to the loçpward. Although tne? members of the team were armed with revolvers, tommy-guns and hand grenades just in case of trouble, Capt. Patrick Teel of New York City, who was with the flrst Ranger battalion at Anzio, said Itll take just five minutes to make us all dead ducks. The flight to Korea from Sian en tailed a journey of almost 1,000 miles over Japanese occupied terri tory. As the plane got within 500 miles of Keijo the radio operator, Lt. Meredith L. Price of Charleston, W. Va., attempted to establish contact with the Japanese. We are expecting you and we guarantee you safe conduct, the Japanese said. When the plane landed, Maj. Gen. Junjiro Ihara, chief of staff for the Japanese forces in Korea, asked Col- Sird his mission.  Just Looking Around. The American officer replied that he was in Korea as the initial pre- Allied occupation representative to bring whatever help is needed by Allied prisoners of war and to make preliminary arrangements for fu ture evacuation in accordance with the terms of the peace negoti ations. Then youre not here to negotiate a surrender? Ihara asked. No, our mission is purely humanitarian, Bird replied. Ihara said that the prisoners were well and were being cared for. but that the party could not see them. During supper that night the Jap- anese were quite convivial. After singing Japanese soncs, one asked, What is the American air force song? Led by Capt. John Wagoner of the air transport command, from Grand Island, Neb., the Americans let loose with the chorus of Off we go into the wild blue yonder. The Japanese beamed and beat time on the table with their fingers. After the Americans finished, the Japanese sang their air force sons The Fighting Wing. The next day the atmosphere be came tense again. When Bird asked a Japanese officer to sign a note saying the mission had arrived but was refused permission to act, the major swore and made stinging ref erences to inferior persons. Shortly afterward the guard around the plane was increased. The gasoline finally was poured into the big ship and the Americans and Koreans took off on the return flight.

document.text: Observe Fiftieth Wedding Anniversary Delayed The Episcopal Parish House of Marion, S. C., was the scene Tuesday afternoon, July 7, from five-thirty until seven o c ock of a lovely tea given by the children of Mr. and Mrs. James Rawlings Hubbard, celebrating the fiftieth anniversary of their marriage. On July 7, 1903, in Washington, D. L., Miss Lillian May Adams of Rich mond, Va. became the bride of James Rawlings Hubbard of Appo mattox, Va. _ ___ Greeting the guests at the door were Mrs. William L. Hubbard of Marion, and Frank C. Hughes of Myrtle Beach, son-in-law of the honor guests. Composing the receiving line were Mr. and Mrs. Hubbard, their chil dren, William L. Hubbard, Marion Mrs. Frank G. Hughes, Myrtle Beach J. Irvin Hubbard, Raeford, N. C., and Bernard R. Hubbard, Marion and Mrs. John C. Moore, Sr., Appomattox, Va., sister of Mr. Hubbard. . Artistic arrangements of gladioli in white and shades of yellow inter- sposed with white phlox, were dot ted about the room where the guests gathered. The piano held an outstanding arrangement of asters and dubrum lilies. Appropriate mu- __l selections were rendered throughout the hours of the tea by Mrs. E. B. Hamner. The table, overlaid with a hand some white linen and lace cloth, was centered with a fan - shaped arrangement of gladioli and gold chrysanthemums. A beautifully em bossed four-tiered wedding cake stood at one end of the table, while the other held the crystal punch bowl, where Mrs. William G. Hub bard presided. Ice cream in the shape of bells and individual wedding cakes were served by Mrs. Graydon Martin, of Appomattox, Va. Mrs. Eugene Fox- worth, Quantico, Va. Mrs. Emily Sawyer, Dillin-. and Miss Betty Lou McGee, of Florence. Passing mints were Misses Lillian Hubbard and Connie Qulla, of Marion and Miss Katherine Ann Hughes, of Myrtle Beach. Also assisting in serving were Kawlings liuuaiu ana win- iam L. Hubbard, Jr., of Marion, and Franklin Hughes, Jr., of Myrtle Beach, grandsons of the honor guests. document.text: Norfolk.The properties of the Mbemarle and Chesapeake Canal Company in Virginia and North Caro lina, consisting of a 10 1-4-mile canal and several thousand acres of land, were sold under foreclosure at Ports mouth, to a committee representing first mortgage bondholders for 300,- 000. This is a link in the proposed governmental intra-costal waterway between Boston and Beaufort, N. C. and has already been recommended for such use by army engineers. The sale was to satisfy a 500,000 30- year bond issue given in 1879 to the Union Trust Company, of New York, trustee. A second mortgage of 230,- 000 was held by the Central Trust Company, of New York. The only bid was by the first mortgage bond- holding committee, composed oi James M. EM wards, Robert L. Harri son and Henry T. Cutter, of New York. The property will be offered to the government for 500,000. Suffolk.-Petitions praying Circuit Judge James L. McLemore to order a local option election to December were put Into circulation here Nearly ail of the required 160 signa tures have been gotten, and the elec tion is assured. Those advocating the contest declare they will seek to eliminate the bitterness which characterized Suffolks - previous wet and  dry fights, and will in vite a dispassionate consideration oi the problem in view of nearly two years  dry experience. Suffolb four years ago went  wet by 11 and two years later voted  dry by 257 IVarrenton, Va. Dr. James Rich ard Sowers, one of the oldest prac titioners here, died at his home aftei a brief illness, at the age of 64 years Dr. Sowers was a native of Clarke county, Virginia, and studied medi cine at Columbian College of Wash ington. In 1865 he married Miss Mary Frances Smith, daughter oi John Smith, and moved to Fauqulei county, where he bad resided evei since. Dr. Sowers was a member ol Mosbys men, and held a gallant wat record. He was a lifelong member of the Baptist Church. Fredericksburg. The new depot of the Richmond, Fredericksburg and Potomac railroad ln this city was thrown open to the public. It le finished throughout in chestnut. The floors are of terazzo, with separate waiting rooms for white and colored people. Electric and gas lights are used. There is an electric clock, and the building is heated by steam. Ornamental grounds surrounding the  structure, and a paved driveway af- 1 fords ample vehicle facilities. I Christiansburg.Five of the six  prisoners who escaped from the Montgomery County Jail have been captured and taken to the penitenti ary at Richn ond. The telephone operator at Kiuld, five miles from here, looked out of a window and saw the men passing. He telephoned to some neighbors, who seized guns and captured the fugitives. They were armed only with sticks. Harrisonburg.The people of the Spring Creek neighborhood have raised 500 for Mr. and Mrs. Henry Wood and seven children, who were left homeless and penniless by a fire that destroyed their residence three weeks ago. In addition great quan tities of food and clothing were con tributed. Mrs. Wood escaped from the house in her night clothes. Roanoke. A survey of a proposed route for a new railroad to be built from Roanoke to Mount-Airy, N. C., via Floyd Courthouse, will begin this week. The announcement was made by McGee and Royer, Roanoke engi neers, who have been employed to make the survey. Two corps of engineers have been engaged. Orange.  Virginius Randolph Shackelford, a prominent young law yer and son of Circuit Judge and Mrs. Geo. S. Shackelford, and Miss Peachy G. Lyne were married in St. Thomas Episcopal Church, in Orange, by Rev. R. S. Carter. The grooms father was the best man. Lynchburg.Three hundred stu dents at Randolph-Macon Womans College accompanied the representa tives from 20 womens colleges whe are attending the convention of the American Womans Inter-Collegiate Association for a visit to the Natural Bridge. The trip was made by spec ial train. Winchester.A horse driven by George Cochran ran off near here and collided with a vehicle occupied by Mrs. Clark Cather and Miss Edna Whetzel, of Clearbrook, this county, and Miss Ella Huyett, of Maryland. All were thrown out and Cochran was badly cut and bruised. Lynchburg.J . N. Burnett, of this city, who recently suffered the death of an infant child from infantile paralysis, has another child ill of the same malady. Fredericksburg. Miss Mary V Caywood, of King George county, left a few days ago for El Paso, Texas, in search of health, being a consump tive. When she reached Washing ton she was too weak to continue the journey. She continued to grow weaker and died in that city. Lexington.A verdict in seven minutes was brought in by the jury for murder iu the first degree against Harry Sltlington, colored, for the murder of Miss Fannie Brown Octo ber 22, 1910, at her home on.W alk ers creek. Lynchburg. At Rocky Mount, a grand jury indicted William Moody a Federal deputy marshal, for al leged interference with election offi cers at Snydersville precinct in Franklin county, this State. Norfolk. In order to test the re sisting power of armor plate when it comes in direct contact with high ex plosives, tbe monitor Puritan, which 10 years ago cost 1,600,000, will be blown to pieces in Norfolk harbor. Lynchburg. Rev. A. E. Baker, o! Lumberton. N. C-, has accepted the call to the pastorate of tbe Rivermont Presbyterian Church.

document.text: Mrs. Robert A . Eagle , 1 M rs. Frances Templeton Eagle, 56, 4829 Tyreeanna Road, died at 1110 a.m . Wednesday in Lynchburg Ge neral Hospital. She was the wife of Robert Asa Eagle. Born in Bedford County, she was a daughter of the late Tommie Lou and Mary Jones Tem pleton. She was past president of Concord Volunteer Fire Department Auxiliary, a member of Tyreeanna Exten sion Homemakers Club and Tyreeanna United Methodist Church. In addition to her husband, she is survived by a son, R. Stanley Eagle, and a daughter, Cheryl L . Eagle, both of Lynchburg a brother, Curtis T. Templeton, Lynchburg four sisters, Lois T. Tomlinson and Mary Ellen T. Willoughby, both of Lynchburg, Ethel T. Manley. Big Island, and Christine T. Campbell, Evington, and a granddaughter,  Tracy Lynn Eagle, Lynchburg. document.text: Michael Kellys Terrible Work at Ltavea- wortb, Kansas. Leavenworth, Kan. Special. Mich ael Kelly, an insane man, at the office of the Robert Garrett Lumber Com pany, in the business district, shot six persons,. killing one, probably fatally wounding another and more or less seriously wounding four others. He was himself finally killed by officers who tried to overpower him. Kelly had lived in Leavenworth for years and at different times engaged in minor business enterprises. He was eccentric, and during the Presidential campaign in 1896 lost his mind entirely. At that time he threatened to kill Gar rett. He was arrested and adjudged insane, Garrett and four others testify ing against him. After a year in the Topeka Asylum Kelly was released. Recently he had been acting queerly again, and declared that he would kill the five men who sent him to the asy lum. For the last two weeks he has been practicing shooting with a pistol at the Fort Leavenworth range. Tues day night he drank heavily. Soon after noon Wednesday he went to Garretts office and without warning shot Garrett as he sat at his desk. Garrett fell to the floor and Kelly de liberately fired four more shots into the body. Leaving his victim for dead, Kelly ran to the rear of the lumber yard and began reloading his pistol. Returning to the office he found Dr. McGee, who had been attracted by the shooting, bending over Garrett. Kelly fired at the physician, the bullet strik ing Dr. McGee in the spise, and he fell near where Garrett lay. Then followed an exciting street fight between the madman and officers who came upon the scene. Kelly, flourish ing his pistol, ran through the lumber yard. He met Isaac Healer, a laborer, and shot him in the hand. A few yards further on he encountered Sergeant Dodge. The two exchanged shots as they ran. One bullet from Kellys weapon struck Dodge in the neck, but not before that officer had shot the madman in the shoulder. Kelly kept running and was soon confronted by Detective McDonald and Policeman  Falthager. McDonald dropped Kelly  with a bullet in the neck. Dodge raised 1 his pistol but it failed to work, and  catching up with the murderer he crushed his skull with the weapon. Kelly was carried to the station in an unconscious condition, dying soon after his arrival.

J.A baseball rain check issued at the Polo Grounds, New York, and saved from the afternoon of the day William Giberson was shot, convinced county officials that they could not connect Harry Ganun, of New York, with the killing for which Mrs. William Giberson is now under arrest. Ganun showed the pasteboard to Prosecutor Jayne, and in addition gave a satisfactory alibi for the eve ning hours, Mr. Jayne said. Another development in the case came when George McGee, of Lake Hurst, toll! the prosecutor he had seen Giberson arguing heatedly in front of bis home with two men on Sunday morning. The two men, one short and one rather tall, are believed to be the couple from whom Giberson won some money in a craps game Sunday eve- I Hog, the prosecutor said.

document.text: Iowa Republican Congressman Bill Scherle calls it a blueprint to fleece the taxpayers pockets. Another Iowan, GOP Rep. H. R. Gross, sees it as an almost incredible, unconscionable move at this moment. What has aroused their congressional ire is a move on the part of some of their colleagues to push for a pay raise for members of Congress and other top federal officials. The lawmakers how receive 42,500 a year. Under the proposals, that figure would be increased to somewhere between 55,400 and 58,400 by 1977. A pay raise - to 52,800 by 1976 - was lulled last March by a 71-to-26 vote in the Senate. Pay hike proponents are now hoping to get favorable action by the present Congress, which includes 92 lame-duck members of the House who were defeated in the recent election and who could vote on the issue without being concerned, at least for the immediate future, about political repercus sions. And all the rest of the members of Congress could vote with the knowledge that they wont face an election at least until two years from now, by which time any public resentment over pay raise action now may be forgotten. Chairman Gale W. McGee of the Senate Post Office and Civil Service Committee, says that pay increase proposals have been drafted but he indicates that no effort will be made to get them through Congress unless President Ford gives his backing.

document.text: DOMESTIC Vice President Fairbanks delivered an address and paid a splendid tribute to President Roosevelt at the celebration oj the golden jubilee of the Republican party of Chester county, Pa., at West Chester. According to a Russian correspond ent, war operations continued the past week in Manchuria. Each day since the peace treaty was signed has seen the shedding of blood uselessly. Baron Komura and Minister Taka- hira took lunch with President Roose velt, and in the evening Mr. Witte and Baron de Rosen were the Presidents guests at dinner. The historic elm at Cambridge, Mass., which marks the spot where Washing ton assumed command of the Army, is believed to be doomed. After eight men of his crew had been lost, Capt. Isaac Frazer, of the Boston fishing schooner Joseph H. Cromwell, committed suicide. Jacob H. Thompson, an editor on the New York Times, was found murdered in his room at the St. James Hotel, in New York. Corporal Tanner was elected comman der-in-chief of the Grand Army of the Republic, whose encampment is in pro gress at Denver, Col. Minneapolis was chosen as national encampment city in 1906. United States mail delivery wagons were acompanied through the streets of New York by a police guard because of demonstrations against the new drivers by the drivers on strike. President Roosevelt has designated Judge W. L. Penfield, solicitor of the State Department, to investigate the trade relations between Europe and South America. Secretary of the Treasury Shaw was one of the principal speakers at the an nual outing of the Vermont Fish and Game League at Bluff Point, N. Y. During a fire in a crowded tenement in New York an Italian lost his life in a vain effort to rescue his two children, both under 10 years of age. The President is in receipt of con gratulations from the Emperor of China for his efforts in restoring peace between Russia and Japan. The Chicago police say they have cap tured a band of women robbers who operated under the guise of nuns. The United Spanish War Veterans will hold their 1906 encampment at Washing ton, D. C. The yellow fever situation in the city of New Orleans is steadily improving, only 35 new cases being reported and sijc deaths. An invasion of millions of marsh mosquitoes gave, the city a bad fright. The strike of the 300 mail drivers in New York city did not interfere with the delivery of the mail. There were early in the,day more applicants than there were positions vacant. Two persons were killed and 30 in jured as the result of a collision between an excursion train and a regular passen ger train near Newcastle, O. John E. Lanning, receiver of the Mon mouth Trust and Safe Deposit Company of Asbury Park, N. J., has sued a number of directors. A fast passenger train ran into a party of workmen at Homewood Station, near Pittsburg, killing two and seriously in juring three others. Town Marshal H. G. Porter, of Mc- Connellsville, O., was shot and killed on the street by Woodie Stewart, a de mented man. One man was killed and several ser iously hurt by the premature explosion of a charge of dynamite at Saxon, Pa. Dr. W. J. McGee is reported to have discovered how storms are bred in the storm-breeding belt of Arizona. A site for a home for consumptive let ter-carriers was donated by the people of Colorado Springs, Col. The State of Georgia has proclaimed a general quarantine against all fever infected points.

document.text: A W in terB a th ln Alaska. Up in Alaska the method of tak ing a bath is somewhat heroic, re marked John S. McGee. Every, trading post has a bath house, and thé people are supposed to avail themselves of its privileges once a week. A person accustomed to liv ing in a milder climate would have mnch hesitanoy abont undressing in one of these places, as the temper ature is always below zero. In an inner room an arch of stones is so built that a fire beneath can pene trate through. A trap in the roof nswers for a ohimney. After tbe stones have become thoroughly heated and the smoke has passed ont, all the coals are removed and the trap door closed In this room stands a cask of warm water and another that is ice-cool. When the bather enters he ponrs hot water on the stones nntill the room is filled with steam  then, taking a seat on a bench, he waits till the perspira tion streams from every pore in his body. Next he takes a bunch of dried twigs and leaves, prepared for the purpose, with which he scrubs himself till all the impuri ties have been removed from the skin, following this with a wash off in warm water and soap. He con cludes his bath by dashing a backet of ioe-oool water over his body, and then rushing to the dressing room, where, with bis teeth chattering, he resumes his clothes.

Mr. John G annaw ay, of Lynchburg, accom panied by a party of ladies passed here on Friday en route to the home of Mr. G annaw ays sister, Mrs. N. Crute. Mr. Shackelford, the district dem onstrator in farm ing m et hods, w as here on the 16 th and addressed farm ers representing nearly all the districts of the County. document.text: B u c k in g h a m i Hon. Richard E. Byrd came to Dillwyn last Saturday driv ing up from New Canton w ith Hon. A. J. Terrill and he de livered an address th a t held to gether his audience of business men of Dillwyn and business men who had come to Dillwyn from widely divergent parts Jof the county to hear the speak ing Mr. Byrd is a good mixer, a good stum p speaker, and in private converse and on the hustings he m akes a good im pression. The boys, however, have a good joke on Speaker Byrd, he drew a word picture of w hat ills the Republican party had done since they had held the reins of the N ational Government, but instead of saying the Republican party he said th a t the Democratic party was responsible for this state of things a ripple of secret laughter passed through the audience and one of his auditors said sotto voce  we will hare to call him Byrd down, but the speaker was ! deep in his theme and did not notice his m istake. Hon. E. W. H ubard, in response to calls made for him , m ade a fine speech, his words were well chosen and his argum ent was as good as the best we have been hearing. Messrs. Jackson, Moon and Boatwright, commissioners, sold the old Greely m ine at Dillwyn on the 26th inst. The purchase price was 2600 and the purchaser w as Mr. Andrew Ford, of New York. M r.Pord m arried a grand-daughter of j the late Horace Greely and his wife inherited a share in this mine property.
